Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Evolution of virulence in a host-pathogen system
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will improve our understanding of the evolution of infectious disease systems while also contributing to education and the development of conservation strategies for protecting amphibian diversity. Disease epidemics rarely end in the complete extinction of host populations. Especially in highly lethal diseases, theory predicts a shift away from the outbreak phase to a post-outbreak stage where hosts and pathogens persist in a shared environment. Such transitions in disease states present a moving target that limits the development of successful intervention strategies. This research investigates the factors that drive evolutionary shifts in disease dynamics by focusing on one of the most devastating infectious diseases of vertebrates in recorded history, amphibian chytridiomycosis. Chytridiomycosis is caused by a fungal pathogen that can spread rapidly through amphibian populations and cause extremely high levels of mortality, suggesting that it is a strong agent of natural selection. This disease has caused - and continues to cause - dramatic losses of amphibian biodiversity around the world. The investigators are using an in-depth understanding of chytridiomycosis to develop science-based conservation strategies. The research is integrated with educational outreach, including public workshops and presentations centered on the annual International Save the Frogs Day.

This research capitalizes on a decade of research in Central America and on an unprecedented archive of disease data, pathogen isolates, and host samples. Pathogen isolates and host samples were collected and archived during the outbreak phase of the disease and similar data are being collected during the endemic phase, beginning eight to ten years later. The researchers are using experimental and molecular methods to investigate the hypotheses that (1) the level of pathogen virulence has shifted since the original outbreaks and (2) that hosts have evolved to be more tolerant of infection. To test these hypotheses, the investigators are testing the historic and contemporary samples to identify phenotypic and genetic differences linked to pathogen virulence host immune defenses. The results will provide insights for safeguarding amphibian biodiversity and for understanding the role of evolution in shaping post-epidemic dynamics of emerging infectious diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Emerging infectious diseases are a global concern. Disease outbreaks can be devastating for host populations, but also provide an opportunity to address gaps in our knowledge about how infectious diseases work. For example, we need to better understand how disease outbreaks subside and become less deadly. We studied how infection patterns change over time in a lethal infectious disease. We expected that disease severity could subside if 1) the pathogen becomes weaker, 2) the host immune responses become stronger, or 3) both occur at the same time. 

 

To address these questions, this project focused on a disease known as amphibian chytridiomycosis. Chytridiomycosis is a deadly fungal disease that impacts frogs, toads, salamanders, and other amphibians. This disease has caused, and continues to cause, dramatic losses of amphibian biodiversity around the world. The investigators conducted this research in Central America, where this chytridiomycosis caused severe outbreaks in amphibian populations over a decade ago. The research team repeatedly visited the same sites and collected pathogen, host, and environmental samples over time. They found that some amphibian species have persisted in these areas, even though they carry the pathogen and show no signs of disease. In addition, they found that the pathogen, and its ability to cause disease and mortality, has not changed substantially since the original outbreaks. In contrast, some of host immune samples in persisting amphibians were dramatically better at halting pathogen growth compared to the same host immune samples that were collected prior to outbreaks. These results suggest that the change in the disease severity resulted from a shift in host immunity, not in the pathogen biology. 

 

This study combined cutting-edge experiments with field studies on pathogen biology and host immune defenses in several threatened and endangered species of amphibians. As such, this research contributed to society by informing strategies to protect amphibian biodiversity in Central America and around the world. The investigators joined, and continue to serve, on scientific advisory boards for multiple amphibian conservation initiatives. They also developed local science programs to increase the understanding of wildlife conservation and infectious disease threats in Central America. 

 

This project was uniquely positioned to advance our basic scientific knowledge of emerging infectious diseases. The research team uncovered some of the key causes of shifting dynamics in a deadly infectious disease system. As such, the scientific results of this project have contributed to scientists? efforts to build a wider understanding of deadly infectious diseases. This outcome is especially important for informingscientists working on other infectious disease problems that threaten plant (e.g., agricultural crops), wildlife, and human health. 

 

Finally, this project was also successful in broadening participation through training and research engagement for students, postdocs, community members, and the general public. The education and outreach activities were an integral part of the research. The investigators? efforts helped to encourage youth participation in scientific research, increase awareness of the loss of amphibian biodiversity, and highlight importance of advancing our understanding of infectious disease.
